entry.et: Middle English sek, sik, from Old English sēoc; akin to Old High German sioh sick

def.dt: :affected with disease or ill health :ailing
:of, relating to, or intended for use in sickness sick pay a sick ward
:queasy nauseated sick to one's stomach was sick in the car
:undergoing menstruation
:spiritually or morally unsound or corrupt
:sickened by strong emotion sick with fear worried sick
:having a strong distaste from surfeit :satiated sick of flattery
:filled with disgust or chagrin gossip makes me sick
:depressed and longing for something sick for one's home
:mentally or emotionally unsound or disordered :morbid sick thoughts
:highly distasteful :macabre sadistic sick jokes a sick crime
:lacking vigor :sickly: as
:badly outclassed made the competition look sick
:incapable of producing profitable yields of a crop sick soils
:vomit 1
:chase attack usually used as a command especially to a dog sic 'em
:to incite or urge to an attack, pursuit, or harassment :set sicced their lawyers on me
:thoroughly fatigued or bored
:fed up
:a compartment in a ship used as a dispensary and hospital
:a place for the care of the sick or injured

:a set of symptoms (as headache, fatigue, and eye irritation) typically affecting workers in modern airtight office buildings that is believed to be caused by indoor pollutants (as formaldehyde fumes or microorganisms) compare multiple chemical sensitivity
:a scheduled time at which individuals (as soldiers) may report as sick to the medical officer
:a paid day of sick leave
:migraine
:an absence from work permitted because of illness
:the number of days per year for which an employer agrees to pay employees who are sick
